instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 1 second, stops and repeats
threads.message: All rails present, rails after <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulse as the fan turns on, clean board, no RAM beeps, customer states that it just stopped working.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 1 second, stops and repeats
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too?
Also check for pulse at CPU coils; as other big coils too.

Inspect <CHIP>U2750</CHIP>/60 and post voltages and pulses at their pins.

Check all power rails from pages 60/61.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 1 second, stops and repeats
threads.message:
Yes [COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too 
Not all the big coils pulse[/FONT][/COLOR] [LEFT][COLOR=#007000]<CHIP>U2750</CHIP> pin5 3.3v, pin4 0v, pin2 pulses below 0v, pin1 pulses 3.3v to 0v
<CHIP>U2760</CHIP>[/COLOR][COLOR=#007000] pin5 3.3v, pin4 0v, pin2 pulses 3.3v tp 0v, pin1 0v
Power Rails
ppbus 8.39v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulses 5v to 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> pulses 5v to 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> pulses
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> pulses
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> pulses[/COLOR]
[/LEFT]

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 1 second, stops and repeats
threads.message:
So no pulse at all at L7510/50?
Check if <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is good.
You can try known good working BIOS, just for test.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 1 second, stops and repeats
threads.message: Correct, no pulse on L7510/50, <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> is good at 90k, I will try to get good BIOS

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 1 second, stops and repeats
threads.message: New BIOS did it, thanks!!!! One board at least!
